hotels.name: Janu Tokyo
hotels.desc: Ultra-modern luxury in Azabudai Hills, Aman sister brand, futuristic design
hotels.longDesc: A breathtaking Aman sister property in Azabudai Hills with minimalist interiors, world-class spa, and dining that rivals the best in Tokyo. Ideal for design-obsessed families.

hotels.name: Bvlgari Hotel Tokyo
hotels.desc: Italian luxury in Yaesu, jeweler's elegance, Roma marble throughout
hotels.longDesc: Bvlgari's Japan debut showcases Italian craftsmanship with precious materials, commanding Tokyo Station views, and a celebrated Il Ristorante for refined family dinners.

hotels.name: Tokyo Edition
hotels.desc: Contemporary design hotel in Toranomon, art-filled, near Imperial Palace
hotels.longDesc: Marriott's design-forward flagship merges contemporary art with Japanese craft traditions in Toranomon, offering curated cultural experiences and locally sourced dining.

hotels.name: Hotel Okura
hotels.desc: Legendary 1962 modernist icon, impeccable service, recently restored
hotels.longDesc: Japan's most storied luxury hotel, lovingly renovated to preserve its iconic mid-century architecture while modernizing rooms. The lobby alone is worth the visit.

hotels.name: Hoshinoya Tokyo
hotels.desc: Luxury urban ryokan in Otemachi, rooftop onsen, kaiseki dinners
hotels.longDesc: A rare urban ryokan steps from the Imperial Palace, blending tatami rooms, traditional kaiseki, and a stunning rooftop onsen into a serene city escape.

hotels.name: K5 Tokyo
hotels.desc: Boutique design hotel in 1920s bank, Nihonbashi, five intimate suites
hotels.longDesc: A beautifully converted 1920s bank building with just five suites, curated art, a craft cocktail bar, and proximity to Nihonbashi's artisan food scene.

hotels.name: Tokyo Station Hotel
hotels.desc: Historic 1914 Beaux-Arts landmark, in-station luxury, Belle Ã‰poque grandeur
hotels.longDesc: Housed within the ornate 1914 Tokyo Station building, offering century-old grandeur, a Michelin-starred restaurant, and unmatched transit convenience.

hotels.name: Park Hyatt Tokyo
hotels.desc: Shinjuku tower, soaring views, New York Grill, renovated 2025
hotels.longDesc: The iconic Lost in Translation hotel, freshly renovated, with sweeping 52nd-floor city views, the legendary New York Grill, and a world-class spa.

hotels.name: Trunk Hotel
hotels.desc: Design-forward social hotel in Cat Street, Shibuya, creative community hub
hotels.longDesc: A curated social hotel on Shibuya's Cat Street blending Scandinavian-Japanese design, a buzzy restaurant, and a cultural community space favored by creatives.

hotels.name: Gora Kadan
hotels.desc: Hakone's premier onsen resort, volcanic hot springs, exquisite kaiseki
hotels.longDesc: A venerable Hakone ryokan with seven natural onsen pools, refined multi-course kaiseki, and mountain serenity that makes it one of Japan's most celebrated retreats.

hotels.name: Hotel Mitsui Hakone
hotels.desc: Contemporary luxury in Hakone, Lake Ashi views, private open-air onsen
hotels.longDesc: Modern luxury meets traditional hospitality with floor-to-ceiling lake views, private rotenburo baths, and a curated art collection in Hakone's quieter southern shore.

hotels.name: Six Senses Kyoto
hotels.desc: Wellness-focused luxury near Higashiyama, sustainable design, Japanese healing
hotels.longDesc: An eco-conscious sanctuary integrating Kyoto's spiritual traditions with contemporary wellness, sourcing locally for kaiseki and offering deeply personalized cultural programs.

hotels.name: Sowaka Kyoto
hotels.desc: Boutique machiya inn in Gion, intimate geisha district immersion
hotels.longDesc: An intimate Gion residence in a beautifully restored machiya, where guests experience tea ceremony, private cypress baths, and the sounds of the geisha quarter.

hotels.name: Four Seasons Kyoto
hotels.desc: Grand luxury with 800-year-old ikeniwa pond garden, Higashiyama
hotels.longDesc: A serene Higashiyama property built around an extraordinary 800-year-old pond garden, with kaiseki dining pavilions and cultural programming led by local artisans.

hotels.name: Aman Kyoto
hotels.desc: Hidden forest retreat in northern Kyoto, moss-covered grounds, total privacy
hotels.longDesc: Tucked into a secret forest in northern Kyoto with moss-covered grounds, paper-screen pavilions, and an atmosphere of contemplative stillness found nowhere else.

hotels.name: Tawaraya Ryokan
hotels.desc: Japan's most prestigious inn since 1709, imperial heritage, Kyoto institution
hotels.longDesc: The most revered ryokan in Japan, hosting guests since 1709, with exquisite kaiseki, immaculate tatami rooms, and a level of hospitality that defines Japanese omotenashi.

hotels.name: Capella Kyoto
hotels.desc: Kengo Kuma-designed 2025 opening near Nijo Castle, ultramodern luxury
hotels.longDesc: A stunning 2025 arrival designed by Kengo Kuma adjacent to Nijo Castle, fusing cutting-edge architecture with Kyoto's cultural depth and Michelin-caliber dining.

hotels.name: Ace Hotel Kyoto
hotels.desc: Kengo Kuma design in historic Shin-Puh-Kan, design-forward community hotel
hotels.longDesc: Kengo Kuma transformed a landmark Shin-Puh-Kan building into a design hotel with local artisan partnerships, a rooftop bar, and Kyoto's most creative community energy.

hotels.name: Waldorf Astoria Osaka
hotels.desc: Osaka's luxury flagship in Umeda, contemporary design, Michelin dining
hotels.longDesc: A commanding Umeda property with sweeping city views, Japanese-influenced interiors, a Michelin-starred restaurant, and refined service in Osaka's business heart.

hotels.name: Patina Osaka
hotels.desc: 2025 design hotel in Nakanoshima art island, creative community focus
hotels.longDesc: A bold 2025 arrival on Nakanoshima's emerging art island, emphasizing local artisan collaborations, contemporary design, and dining showcasing Osaka's culinary innovators.

hotels.name: Hyatt Centric Kanazawa
hotels.desc: Contemporary luxury near Kenrokuen, walkable to samurai and geisha quarters
hotels.longDesc: A sleek modern property in Kanazawa with refined design, walkable access to Kenrokuen Garden and the samurai and geisha districts, and a restaurant celebrating Kaga cuisine.

hotels.name: Beniya Mukayu
hotels.desc: One of Japan's finest ryokans, Yamashiro Onsen, Ishikawa mountain hospitality
hotels.longDesc: A legendary Ishikawa ryokan with private mineral-rich onsen, kaiseki dinners by a celebrated chef, and generations of mountain hospitality that define the ryokan experience.

hotels.name: Byaku Narai
hotels.desc: Historic Edo-era inn on Nakasendo Trail, Narai-juku post-town charm
hotels.longDesc: A beautifully restored inn within the preserved Edo-era post-town of Narai-juku, offering kaiseki from mountain ingredients and an authentic Nakasendo Trail experience.

hotels.name: Asaba Ryokan
hotels.desc: Shuzenji Onsen legend, Izu gorge views, Noh stage, Michelin 3-Key
hotels.longDesc: One of Japan's most acclaimed ryokans in Shuzenji with a private Noh stage, gorge-view baths, and kaiseki sourcing local mountain vegetables. A bucket-list stay.

hotels.name: Hoshinoya Karuizawa
hotels.desc: Premier mountain resort surrounded by forest, contemporary ryokan innovation
hotels.longDesc: A luxury mountain retreat in pristine Karuizawa forest with flowing-water village design, private onsen, and kaiseki featuring seasonal highland ingredients.

hotels.name: Zaborin
hotels.desc: Niseko's exclusive 15-villa hideaway, private onsen, Hokkaido fine dining
hotels.longDesc: An ultra-luxury 15-villa property in Niseko where every suite has its own private onsen, and the restaurant sources exclusively from Hokkaido's finest producers.

hotels.name: Park Hyatt Niseko
hotels.desc: Niseko's five-star mountain resort, ski-in/ski-out, year-round alpine luxury
hotels.longDesc: A landmark ski-in/ski-out property with panoramic mountain views, multiple Hokkaido-focused restaurants, and year-round activities from powder skiing to summer hiking.

hotels.name: Setsu Niseko
hotels.desc: Intimate 20-room Niseko boutique, Japanese minimalism, Michelin Key awarded
hotels.longDesc: A refined 20-room property where Japanese minimalism meets alpine luxury, with natural hot spring onsen, a celebrated restaurant, and exclusive ski access.

hotels.name: The Windsor Hotel Toya
hotels.desc: Lake Toya clifftop grandeur, G8 summit venue, Michelin-starred dining
hotels.longDesc: A prestigious clifftop resort overlooking Lake Toya's caldera, known for hosting the G8 summit, with Michelin-starred dining and natural hot spring baths.

hotels.name: We Hotel Toya
hotels.desc: Lake Toya wellness resort, every room with open-air volcanic onsen bath
hotels.longDesc: A contemporary wellness resort where every room features a private open-air bath fed by volcanic springs, with farm-to-table Hokkaido cuisine and lake panoramas.

hotels.name: Fujiya Hotel Ginzan Onsen
hotels.desc: Kengo Kuma-designed icon in gaslit Ginzan Onsen village, Yamagata
hotels.longDesc: The architectural jewel of Ginzan Onsen, redesigned by Kengo Kuma while preserving Meiji-era charm, in a magical gaslit hot spring village that inspired Spirited Away.

hotels.name: Tsuru no Yu
hotels.desc: 300-year-old milky onsen in Nyuto mountains, Akita, most authentic experience
hotels.longDesc: The most famous of Nyuto's seven rustic onsen, with a 300-year-old milky outdoor rotenburo surrounded by beech forest â€” Japan's most authentic hot spring experience.

hotels.name: Kakunodate Sanso Wabizakura
hotels.desc: 10 private onsen spas in samurai town, Kakunodate, Akita cherry blossoms
hotels.longDesc: A tranquil inn within Kakunodate's samurai district offering ten private onsen spas, kaiseki with local Akita ingredients, and stunning views during cherry blossom season.

hotels.name: Noboribetsu Takinoya
hotels.desc: Dramatic waterfall ryokan in Noboribetsu, Hokkaido's volcanic hot spring valley
hotels.longDesc: A luxury Hokkaido ryokan perched above a waterfall in Noboribetsu's volcanic valley, with sulfurous natural springs, traditional kaiseki, and immersive geothermal scenery.

hotels.name: Matsushima Taikanso
hotels.desc: Bay-view ryokan overlooking Matsushima's 260 pine-covered islands, Miyagi
hotels.longDesc: A serene ryokan with panoramic views of Matsushima Bay's 260 pine-forested islands, traditional gardens, and kaiseki emphasizing Miyagi's exceptional seafood.

hotels.name: The Westin Sendai
hotels.desc: Sendai's premier hotel on floors 26-37, city and mountain panoramas
hotels.longDesc: Sendai's highest hotel occupying floors 26-37 with sweeping views of the city and Ou Mountains, convenient to Aoba Castle and the Tohoku Shinkansen.

hotels.name: Satoyama Jujo
hotels.desc: Michelin-starred farm-to-table ryokan in Niigata mountains, modernized folk-house design

hotels.name: Enowa Yufuin
hotels.desc: 2023 farm-to-table luxury in Yufuin, Mt. Yufudake views, hilltop villas with private onsen
hotels.longDesc: A brand-new 2023 hilltop retreat in Oita where a Tibetan-born chef tends his own farm each morning to source extraordinary vegetable-driven kaiseki. Contemporary villas with private onsen and valley panoramas.

hotels.name: Ryotei Hanzuiryo
hotels.desc: Sukiya-style luxury in Unzen, Nagasaki, 300sqm villas, exceptional kaiseki, moss gardens
hotels.longDesc: A 14-room sukiya-style ryokan in Nagasaki's volcanic Unzen region with 300sqm private villas, moss-laden gardens, koi ponds, and kaiseki featuring Ariake Sea puffer fish and local rarities.

restaurants.name: SÃ‰ZANNE
restaurants.desc: 3 Michelin stars, Four Seasons Marunouchi, refined French-Japanese

restaurants.name: Sukiyabashi Jiro Honten

restaurants.name: Saito

restaurants.longDesc: Takayuki Saito's 11-seat shrine to nigiri where each piece reflects pristine sourcing and anatomical precision; silent mastery with minimal garnish.

restaurants.name: Kanda
restaurants.desc: 3 Michelin stars, modern Japanese, Ginza innovation and tradition

restaurants.name: Den

restaurants.longDesc: Zaiyu Hasegawa's whimsical counter in Jingumae serves kaiseki as conceptual theater; each course surprises with technical brilliance and humor.

restaurants.name: Narisawa
restaurants.desc: 2 Michelin stars, satoyama cuisine, foraged ingredients and nature

restaurants.name: FlorilÃ¨ge

restaurants.name: Tempura Kondo
restaurants.desc: Iconic Ginza tempura, soy-dipped mastery, counter tradition since 1930

restaurants.name: Torishiki

restaurants.name: Narukiyo

restaurants.name: Tsukiji Toritoh

restaurants.longDesc: Over-a-century legacy serving only oyakodonâ€”chicken and egg rice bowl where poaching technique defines the creamy, molten yolk.

restaurants.name: Fuunji

restaurants.name: Ichiran Shibuya

restaurants.name: Tsurutontan Udon

restaurants.name: Bar Benfiddich

restaurants.name: Bar High Five

restaurants.name: Mori Bar

restaurants.name: Fugulen Tokyo

restaurants.name: Onibus Coffee

restaurants.name: Kikunoi

restaurants.name: Yasaka

restaurants.name: Roan Kikunoi

restaurants.name: Gion Owatari

restaurants.name: Guilo Guilo Hitoshina

restaurants.name: Bee's Knees

restaurants.name: L'Escamoteur

restaurants.name: Kashiwaya

restaurants.longDesc: Osaka's three-star kaiseki where Kansai tradition meets contemporary artistry; chef's meticulous sourcing of regional ingredients defines seasonal excellence.

restaurants.name: Hajime

restaurants.name: Sushi Harasho
restaurants.desc: Best sushi Osaka, counter omakase, Kobe excellence
restaurants.longDesc: Osaka's supreme sushi counter where Kobe ingredients and meticulous rice technique create omakase progression rivaling Tokyo standards.

restaurants.longDesc: Kanazawa's unique fusion where French classical technique meets Japanese kaiseki rigor; chef's European training reframes Kaga seasonal tradition.

restaurants.longDesc: Morioka's top-rated reimen counter where icy cold noodles meet broth of perfect clarity; Tabelog perfection reflects seasonal technique.

restaurants.name: Bar Andante

experiences.longDesc: Experience Japanese head spa tradition with pressure points designed to melt tension and restore clarity.

experiences.name: Arashiyama Bamboo Grove
experiences.desc: Kyoto's iconic swaying bamboo forest, magical in early morning silence
experiences.longDesc: Wander between 200-year-old bamboo stalks that creak and sway, serene only before tourist crowds arrive.

experiences.name: Hakone Open Air Museum
experiences.desc: Sculpture park with Mount Fuji backdrop and contemporary art integrated into nature
experiences.longDesc: Walk through 60+ artworks by contemporary masters positioned against mountain views and seasonal forests.

experiences.name: Miho Museum
experiences.desc: I.M. Pei's masterpiece tunnel museum in Shiga mountains housing global treasures
experiences.longDesc: Enter through a dramatic glass tunnel carved into forested mountains, revealing a world-class collection designed for contemplation.

experiences.name: La Collina
experiences.desc: Taneya confectionery factory with mountain views and artisanal sweet-making tradition
experiences.longDesc: Watch confectioners craft delicate sweets using century-old techniques in a hilltop workshop overlooking Shiga valleys.

experiences.name: Hakone Kowakien Yunessun
experiences.desc: Quirky theme onsen with unique bathing experiences and creative mineral pools
experiences.longDesc: Soak in themed bathsâ€”coffee, wine, sushi-shaped poolsâ€”while admiring Hakone mountain scenery from Japanese hot springs.

experiences.name: Hakone Yuryo
experiences.desc: Traditional kaiseki and private onsen hotel with refined mountain hospitality
experiences.longDesc: Experience multi-course seasonal kaiseki paired with private mineral baths overlooking mountain valleys and forests.

experiences.name: Maikoya Tea Ceremony
experiences.desc: Authentic matcha preparation in Kyoto with detailed cultural instruction
experiences.longDesc: Learn 400-year rituals of whisking matcha in a traditional space, understanding Zen principles through your hands.

experiences.name: Honen-in Temple
experiences.desc: Peaceful Kyoto temple with sand mandalas, moss paths, and minimal crowds
experiences.longDesc: Discover monks raking intricate sand patterns daily in this quiet temple where art and spirituality merge seamlessly.

experiences.name: Gio-ji Temple
experiences.desc: Arashiyama's intimate historical temple with thatched roof among bamboo forest
experiences.longDesc: Step into a centuries-old story at this secluded bamboo-grove temple honoring tragic historical figures through traditional noh theater.

experiences.name: Sanzen-in Temple
experiences.desc: Ohara's serene temple with moss gardens, painted ceilings, and peaceful visitor atmosphere
experiences.longDesc: Walk through gardens painting natural beauty in green moss and stone, then gaze at Buddha statues beneath painted temple ceilings.

experiences.name: Gran Class Shinkansen
experiences.desc: Japan's premium bullet train with gourmet meals and Mt. Fuji viewing seats
experiences.longDesc: Travel at 320 km/h while enjoying kaiseki dinners and reserved seating for perfect Mount Fuji photo ops.

experiences.name: Nikka Whisky Yoichi
experiences.desc: Hokkaido's legendary whisky distillery set in mountain valley with museum tours
experiences.longDesc: Taste world-award-winning Japanese whisky distilled in pure Hokkaido mountain springs, learning founder Masataka Taketsuru's story.

experiences.name: Farm Tomita
experiences.desc: Furano's iconic lavender farm blooming purple July-August with artisanal products
experiences.longDesc: Walk through fragrant lavender fields rolling toward distant mountains, then explore factory shops crafting aromatic oils and soaps.

experiences.name: Shirogane Blue Pond
experiences.desc: Biei's otherworldly turquoise pond framed by silvery dead trees and mountains
experiences.longDesc: Photograph surreal cobalt watersâ€”colored by mineral sedimentâ€”ringed by bleached larch trees reflecting powder-blue mountain skies.

experiences.name: Otaru Canal
experiences.desc: Historic waterfront with preserved warehouses, gas lamps, and nostalgic Hokkaido charm
experiences.longDesc: Stroll restored Meiji-era warehouses along candlelit stone canal where merchant ships once traded; artisan shops and cafÃ©s now thrive.

experiences.name: Furano Wine Factory
experiences.desc: Working vineyard and winery producing internationally-praised Hokkaido wines
experiences.longDesc: Tour terraced vineyards and sample award-winning Furano wines in a modern facility designed to showcase mountain terroir.

experiences.name: Furano Cheese Factory
experiences.desc: Artisanal cheese maker with observation windows and tasting room in Hokkaido
experiences.longDesc: Watch master cheesemakers craft fresh mozzarella and aged varieties, then taste pairings with local wines and fresh milk.

experiences.name: Matsushima Bay Cruise
experiences.desc: 250-island bay boat tour, Japan's most scenic marine landscape since 1700s
experiences.longDesc: Cruise past pine-dotted islands appearing in ukiyo-e prints, experiencing one of Japan's three most celebrated scenic views.

experiences.name: Ginzan Onsen Village
experiences.desc: Yamagata's preserved snow-country onsen with gas lamps and Meiji-era wooden facades
experiences.longDesc: Walk glowing lantern-lit streets of perfectly preserved hot-spring village where snow falls on wooden bathhouses since the 1920s.

experiences.name: Kakunodate Samurai District
experiences.desc: Akita's atmospheric samurai town with weeping cherry trees and historic residences
experiences.longDesc: Wander cherry-lined lanes past original samurai homes, experiencing feudal-era architecture and cherry blossom season magic.

experiences.name: Dewa Sanzan
experiences.desc: Sacred three-mountain pilgrimage complex honored by monks and pilgrims for 1400 years
experiences.longDesc: Climb misty peaks where white-robed monks practice ancient ascetic rituals among clouds, honoring past and present spirituality.

experiences.name: Nyuto Onsen Village
experiences.desc: Akita's remote mountain hot-spring village with seven traditional bath houses
experiences.longDesc: Soak in seven distinct onsen poolsâ€”each with unique mineral composition and traditional architectureâ€”in pristine mountain forests.

experiences.name: Oirase Gorge
experiences.desc: Aomori's dramatic 14km river gorge with scarlet autumn foliage and hiking trails
experiences.longDesc: Trek alongside emerald waters through towering rock walls ablaze with crimson-gold autumn colors reflected in river mirrors.

experiences.name: Otokoyama Sake Museum
experiences.desc: Asahikawa's historic sake brewery with museum tours and tasting experiences
experiences.longDesc: Learn century-old brewing techniques at Hokkaido's premier sake distillery, tasting award-winning varieties crafted from pure mountain water.

experiences.name: Mt. Hakodate Night View
experiences.desc: Hokkaido's magical nighttime mountain vista, rated world's top three city views
experiences.longDesc: Ascend by cable car to watch 100,000 city lights shimmer below, twin bays glowing like liquid jewels under starlight.

experiences.name: Patchwork Road
experiences.desc: Biei's quilt-like farmland landscape with seasonal color changes and rural roads
experiences.longDesc: Drive through patchwork quilt fields where farmers rotate seasonal crops in geometric patterns against distant Hokkaido mountains.

experiences.name: Live Squid Fishing
experiences.desc: Hakodate's unique night squid fishing experience with boat lanterns attracting luminescent squid
experiences.longDesc: Fish for glowing squid by lanternlight in Hokkaido waters, learning traditional techniques while witnessing the marine spectacle.

experiences.name: Omiya Bonsai Village
experiences.desc: Saitama's 250-year bonsai cultivation district with master artisans and living galleries
experiences.longDesc: Browse dozens of bonsai studios where third-generation masters sculpt miniature centuries-old trees into philosophical living art.

experiences.name: Shimokitazawa Vintage
experiences.desc: Tokyo's bohemian neighborhood packed with vintage shops, theaters, and artistic energy
experiences.longDesc: Hunt through narrow lanes of eclectic vintage boutiques, retro fashion, and live music venues in Tokyo's creative indie district.

experiences.name: Fushimi Sake District
experiences.desc: Kyoto's historic brewery quarter with 100+ sake distilleries, museums, and tastings
experiences.longDesc: Tour riverside sake breweries producing Japan's finest since the 1600s, tasting distinct regional varieties and learning fermentation secrets.

experiences.name: Tsutaya T-Site Daikanyama
experiences.desc: Tokyo's design mecca bookstore showcasing modern architecture and lifestyle curation
experiences.longDesc: Explore Japan's most beautiful bookstoreâ€”a design-focused lifestyle complex featuring architecture books, design objects, and galleries.

experiences.name: Kiyomizu Pottery Street
experiences.desc: Kyoto's centuries-old ceramic workshop lane with live potters and handmade stoneware
experiences.longDesc: Walk downhill past 200+ pottery shops where artisans throw, paint, and glaze traditional Kyoto ceramics using inherited techniques.

experiences.name: Disk Union Shinjuku
experiences.desc: Tokyo's legendary eight-story record and CD mega-store with rare and new vinyl
experiences.longDesc: Dig through eight floors of vinyl, CDs, and music memorabilia at Japan's premier independent record retailer in Shinjuku.

experiences.name: Meiji Jingu
experiences.desc: Tokyo's serene Shinto shrine nestled in primeval forest sanctuary near bustling Shibuya
experiences.longDesc: Wander towering torii gates through ancient forest grove dedicated to Emperor Meiji, discovering peace steps from urban chaos.

experiences.name: Otaru Stained Glass Museum
experiences.desc: Hokkaido's historic warehouse transformed into stunning stained-glass art collection
experiences.longDesc: Discover 150+ European and Japanese stained-glass masterpieces displayed in an atmospheric Meiji-era warehouse on Hokkaido's coast.

experiences.name: Naoshima Art Island
experiences.desc: Tadao Ando museums and contemporary art on islands in Seto Inland Sea
experiences.longDesc: Ferry to this art sanctuary where Tadao Ando's concrete museums house contemporary masterworks reflected in sea light.

experiences.name: Chichu Art Museum
experiences.desc: Underground Naoshima museum showcasing Monet's Water Lilies in dramatic natural light
experiences.longDesc: Enter Ando's subterranean gallery where Monet's late paintings emerge from darkness into changing natural light through skylights.

experiences.name: Kenrokuen Garden
experiences.desc: Kanazawa's masterpiece garden ranked among Japan's top three landscapes
experiences.longDesc: Stroll manicured hills, scenic bridges, and meticulously-pruned trees in one of Japan's most historically significant garden designs.

experiences.name: 21st Century Museum of Art
experiences.desc: Kanazawa's contemporary art museum designed by SANAA with seamless glass architecture
experiences.longDesc: Explore SANAA's transparent modernist design housing contemporary installations where walls blur between art, architecture, and gardens.

experiences.name: Fushimi Inari
experiences.desc: Kyoto's iconic 10,000 vermillion torii gate tunnel hike through sacred fox shrine
experiences.longDesc: Climb through endless crimson torii gates on misty mountain paths where 1300 years of pilgrimage rituals still resonate.

experiences.name: Kinkaku-ji Golden Pavilion
experiences.desc: Kyoto's most photographed gold-leafed temple floating serene in mirror pond garden
experiences.longDesc: Witness the 14th-century gold-covered temple reflected perfectly in garden pools, a meditation on impermanence and beauty.

experiences.name: Nijo Castle
experiences.desc: Kyoto's UNESCO palace with famous nightingale floors and samurai-era architecture
experiences.longDesc: Walk through shogun's residence hearing floors creak intentionally to prevent ninja intrusions, exploring feudal political power centers.

experiences.name: Philosopher's Path
experiences.desc: Kyoto's cherry-blossom canal walk connecting temples through romantic tree-lined canal
experiences.longDesc: Follow 2km stone canal where 600 cherry trees bloom spring pink overhead, inspiring philosophers and artists for over a century.

experiences.name: Senso-ji Temple
experiences.desc: Asakusa's ancient temple gate approach crowded with incense, craft shops, and tradition
experiences.longDesc: Pass beneath Tokyo's oldest 7th-century temple gates through sensory-rich shopping alleys of traditional hand-crafted goods.

experiences.name: Shinjuku Gyoen
experiences.desc: Tokyo's expansive modern gardens blending Japanese, French, and English landscape styles
experiences.longDesc: Explore 58 hectares of curated botanical gardens featuring seasonal blooms, traditional tea houses, and peaceful walking paths.

experiences.name: Nakano Broadway
experiences.desc: Tokyo's beloved vintage shopping complex for anime memorabilia, retro tech, and subculture
experiences.longDesc: Ascend eight floors of anime merchandise, vintage cameras, and collectibles in Tokyo's geek-culture epicenter complex.

experiences.name: Cup Noodles Museum Yokohama
experiences.desc: Interactive ramen history museum where you design and create your own instant noodle bowl
experiences.longDesc: Learn instant ramen's revolutionary history, then craft personalized flavor combinations in this playful, delicious design experience.

kidFriendly.name: ASOBONO
kidFriendly.desc: Massive indoor play complex at Tokyo Dome City, ages 0-6, ball pits and slides
kidFriendly.longDesc: Tokyo's premier indoor playground for babies through age 6, with multi-story slides, ball ponds, water play, and dedicated baby zones inside Tokyo Dome City.

kidFriendly.name: Harajuku Kids Club
kidFriendly.desc: English-speaking drop-off childcare in central Harajuku, ages 0-12
kidFriendly.longDesc: Bilingual childcare facility allowing parents guilt-free shopping time in Harajuku while kids play safely with trained English-speaking staff.

kidFriendly.name: Kiddyland Harajuku
kidFriendly.desc: Iconic five-floor toy paradise in Omotesando, every character imaginable
kidFriendly.longDesc: A legendary five-story toy wonderland on Omotesando featuring character merchandise, collectibles, and creative toys that captivate kids of every age.

kidFriendly.name: Ghibli Museum
kidFriendly.desc: Miyazaki's magical museum in Mitaka, original animation, exclusive short films
kidFriendly.longDesc: An enchanting museum designed by Miyazaki himself, with original animation cels, a rooftop robot soldier, and exclusive short films shown only here. Book well in advance.

kidFriendly.name: Ghibli Park
kidFriendly.desc: 2022 Aichi theme park bringing Ghibli worlds to life, immersive walk-throughs
kidFriendly.longDesc: A sprawling open-air park in Aichi where full-scale Ghibli worlds come to life, including the giant Laputa robot, Totoro's forest, and themed walk-through buildings.

kidFriendly.name: Ueno Zoo
kidFriendly.desc: Japan's oldest zoo with giant pandas, Ueno Park, stroller-friendly paths
kidFriendly.longDesc: Japan's first zoo, home to beloved giant pandas, with spacious stroller-friendly grounds within Ueno Park and excellent rest areas for families with toddlers.

kidFriendly.name: Inokashira Park
kidFriendly.desc: Kichijoji park with swan pedal boats, small zoo, shady lakeside walks
kidFriendly.longDesc: A peaceful lakeside park with swan boat rentals, a small petting zoo, playgrounds, and shady walking paths ideal for toddler exploration near the Ghibli Museum.

kidFriendly.name: Tokyo Toy Museum
kidFriendly.desc: Hands-on wooden toy museum in Yotsuya, craft workshops, ages 0-10
kidFriendly.longDesc: An educational museum in a converted school building featuring thousands of handmade wooden toys, interactive play rooms, and toy-making workshops for kids.

kidFriendly.name: Shinjuku Gyoen
kidFriendly.desc: Serene gardens with wide lawns and playgrounds, peaceful escape from Shinjuku
kidFriendly.longDesc: A tranquil oasis within bustling Shinjuku with expansive lawns, dedicated play areas, and multiple garden styles perfect for toddlers to run freely.

kidFriendly.name: Cup Noodles Museum Yokohama
kidFriendly.desc: Design your own cup noodle, interactive ramen history, ages 3+
kidFriendly.longDesc: An interactive museum where kids design and illustrate their own cup noodle, explore ramen history through play, and enjoy a rooftop art garden.

kidFriendly.name: Odaiba Waterfront
kidFriendly.desc: Tokyo Bay play area with splash pads, beach, giant Gundam statue, views
kidFriendly.longDesc: A modern waterfront with splash pads, a small sand beach, the giant Gundam statue, and wide open spaces along Tokyo Bay with skyline views.

kidFriendly.name: DisneySea
kidFriendly.desc: World's only ocean-themed Disney, gentler rides for toddlers, magical theming
kidFriendly.longDesc: Disney's unique ocean-themed park with numerous toddler-friendly attractions, excellent stroller facilities, and the most visually stunning Disney theming anywhere.

kidFriendly.name: IKE.SUN Park
kidFriendly.desc: Ikebukuro's modern all-weather park with indoor play and outdoor green space
kidFriendly.longDesc: A sleek modern park in Ikebukuro with both climate-controlled indoor play and outdoor green spaces, plus kid-friendly restaurants and cafes on site.

kidFriendly.name: Nara Park
kidFriendly.desc: Friendly wild deer, 1,200 sika deer roam freely, deer crackers available
kidFriendly.longDesc: A magical 660-acre park where 1,200 friendly sika deer roam among ancient temples. Kids can feed them deer crackers â€” an unforgettable gentle animal encounter.

kidFriendly.name: Pokemon Center Kyoto
kidFriendly.desc: Official Pokemon store with Kyoto exclusives, character plushies, trading cards
kidFriendly.longDesc: A dedicated Pokemon retail space in Kyoto's shopping district with region-exclusive items, interactive displays, and the full range of character merchandise.

kidFriendly.name: Kyoto Aquarium
kidFriendly.desc: Modern aquarium with jellyfish tunnel, dolphins, touch tanks, near station
kidFriendly.longDesc: A contemporary aquarium near Kyoto Station featuring a mesmerizing jellyfish tunnel, dolphin shows, interactive touch pools, and exhibits on Kyoto's river ecosystems.

kidFriendly.name: Thomas Land
kidFriendly.desc: Thomas the Tank Engine park at Fuji-Q Highland, gentle rides, Mt Fuji views
kidFriendly.longDesc: A Thomas-dedicated theme area at Fuji-Q Highland with gentle rides and character meet-and-greets, all with stunning Mt. Fuji as the backdrop.

kidFriendly.name: Solaniwa Onsen
kidFriendly.desc: Family onsen paradise in Osaka, warm pools, kid-friendly baths, water slides
kidFriendly.longDesc: Osaka's premier family onsen complex with multiple bath temperatures, water slides, and dedicated child-friendly soaking areas where kids can safely experience Japanese bathing culture.

kidFriendly.name: Kids Plaza Osaka
kidFriendly.desc: Five-floor interactive children's museum, role-play zones, science exhibits
kidFriendly.longDesc: A spectacular five-floor children's museum with career role-play zones, science demonstrations, a Hundertwasser-designed creative floor, and play areas for all ages.

kidFriendly.name: Osaka Aquarium Kaiyukan
kidFriendly.desc: World-class aquarium with whale sharks, ray touch tank, eight Pacific habitats
kidFriendly.longDesc: One of the world's great aquariums, built around a massive central tank with whale sharks, featuring eight Pacific Rim habitat zones and an interactive ray touch pool.

kidFriendly.name: Asahiyama Zoo
kidFriendly.desc: Hokkaido's beloved zoo with penguin walk, seal tunnel, innovative habitats
kidFriendly.longDesc: Japan's most innovative zoo featuring a walk-through penguin parade (winter), a cylindrical seal tank, and close-encounter habitats designed for children's engagement.

kidFriendly.name: Sapporo Maruyama Zoo
kidFriendly.desc: Compact Sapporo zoo near Maruyama Shrine, red pandas, stroller-friendly
kidFriendly.longDesc: A manageable-sized Hokkaido zoo nestled near historic Maruyama Shrine, featuring beloved red pandas and well-paved paths perfect for stroller navigation.

kidFriendly.name: Furano Cheese Workshop
kidFriendly.desc: Hands-on cheese making in Hokkaido, observation windows, playground, ages 2+
kidFriendly.longDesc: A charming Hokkaido cheese factory where kids watch production through windows, taste samples, and play in the adjacent outdoor playground amid beautiful farmland.

kidFriendly.name: Live Squid Fishing
kidFriendly.desc: Catch squid from a Hakodate dock at night, eat your catch fresh, magical
kidFriendly.longDesc: A unique Hakodate evening activity where families fish for glowing live squid from the dock and eat their catch prepared immediately â€” fascinating for kids of all ages.

kidFriendly.name: Matsushima Bay Cruise
kidFriendly.desc: Gentle scenic boat through 260 pine islands, one of Japan's Three Views
kidFriendly.longDesc: A relaxing boat cruise past 260 pine-covered islands, gentle enough for toddlers and strollers, showcasing one of Japan's officially designated most beautiful vistas.

kidFriendly.name: Kakunodate Walking
kidFriendly.desc: Stroller-friendly samurai town, flat stone paths, cherry trees, small museums
kidFriendly.longDesc: A picturesque samurai village with completely flat stone-paved streets ideal for strollers, weeping cherry trees, and small family-friendly museums along the way.

kidFriendly.name: Anpanman Museum Sendai
kidFriendly.desc: Beloved character museum for toddlers, live shows, Anpanman bakery, ages 1-5
kidFriendly.longDesc: An Anpanman-themed paradise for toddlers with interactive play areas, live character stage shows, and a bakery selling character-shaped bread that kids adore.

kidFriendly.name: Sendai Umi no Mori Aquarium
kidFriendly.desc: Modern aquarium with dolphin shows, penguin exhibits, interactive touch pools
kidFriendly.longDesc: A modern Sendai aquarium with engaging dolphin shows, a penguin exhibit, jellyfish gallery, and interactive touch pools perfect for curious young children.

markets.name: Toyosu Market
markets.desc: World's largest wholesale fish market, tuna auctions, sushi restaurants
markets.longDesc: The modern successor to Tsukiji, hosting the famous pre-dawn tuna auctions and some of Tokyo's freshest sushi restaurants, all within a sleek glass-walled facility.

markets.name: Tsukiji Outer Market
markets.desc: Iconic Tokyo food market, 400+ vendors, street food, tamagoyaki, fresh sushi
markets.longDesc: The vibrant surviving outer market with 400+ vendors selling tamagoyaki, fresh sushi, wagyu skewers, and kitchen tools â€” Tokyo's most exciting food walk.

markets.name: Nishiki Market
markets.desc: Kyoto's 400-year-old Kitchen, five blocks of pickles, sweets, seasonal produce
markets.longDesc: Kyoto's beloved 400-year-old food market stretching five blocks, famous for tsukemono pickles, seasonal mochi, matcha everything, and local knife shops.

markets.name: Kuromon Market
markets.desc: Osaka's Kitchen, raw fish counters, takoyaki stands, grilled seafood stalls
markets.longDesc: A lively covered market in Osaka where vendors grill scallops and skewers in front of you, with outstanding raw fish counters and the city's best street takoyaki.

markets.name: Kappabashi Street
markets.desc: Tokyo's kitchen supply wonderland, Japanese knives, food replicas, ceramics
markets.longDesc: A 170-shop kitchen supply street where you'll find handmade Japanese knives, restaurant-grade ceramics, and the incredible plastic food replica workshops.

markets.name: Omicho Market
markets.desc: Kanazawa's 300-year-old kitchen, crab legs, fresh seafood, regional specialties
markets.longDesc: A 300-year-old covered market in Kanazawa famous for enormous crab legs, glistening fresh fish, and local specialties like gold-leaf ice cream.

markets.name: Tsukishima Monja Street
markets.desc: 80+ monjayaki restaurants on one street, Tokyo's savory pancake capital
markets.longDesc: A unique Tokyo neighborhood street lined with 80+ tiny restaurants specializing in monjayaki â€” Tokyo's gooey, savory answer to Osaka's okonomiyaki.

markets.name: Hakodate Morning Market
markets.desc: 250 vendors from dawn, DIY nokke-don, fresh crab, squid fishing tank
markets.longDesc: A bustling dawn market with 250 vendors selling ultra-fresh Hokkaido seafood, a famous DIY rice bowl alley, and a tank where you can fish for live squid.

markets.name: Nijo Market
markets.desc: Sapporo's 100-year-old seafood market, king crab, scallops, uni bowls
markets.longDesc: Sapporo's century-old market overflowing with Hokkaido king crab, giant scallops, and fresh uni bowls â€” the best place to taste Hokkaido's seafood bounty.

markets.name: Tatehana Wharf Morning Market
markets.desc: Japan's largest morning market, 300+ vendors, Hachinohe port, fish auctions
markets.longDesc: Japan's biggest morning market with 300+ vendors selling just-caught fish at Hachinohe port, plus live auctions and a spectacular senbei-jiru soup breakfast.

markets.name: Furukawa Fish Market
markets.desc: DIY nokke-don in Aomori, ticket-based fish-topping system, since 1941
markets.longDesc: An Aomori market famous for its unique nokke-don system where you buy tickets and build your own seafood rice bowl by choosing toppings from different vendors.

markets.name: Foodever
markets.desc: UNESCO Creative City of Gastronomy food hall, Tsuruoka, Shonai regional cuisine
markets.longDesc: A curated food hall in UNESCO-recognized Tsuruoka showcasing Shonai region's extraordinary indigenous vegetables, local sake, and the cuisine that earned the designation.

markets.name: Nakano Broadway
markets.desc: Eight-floor vintage complex, anime, retro cameras, rare collectibles
markets.longDesc: A legendary eight-story complex in Nakano that's paradise for collectors â€” vintage cameras, rare anime figures, retro games, and quirky finds on every floor.

markets.name: Yanaka Ginza
markets.desc: Nostalgic retro shotengai, cat-themed shops, local bakeries, old Tokyo charm
markets.longDesc: A charming retro shopping street preserving old Tokyo character with family-run shops, cat-themed everything, artisan bakeries, and a golden sunset stairway view.

markets.name: Ameya-Yokocho
markets.desc: Ueno's bustling discount market street, snacks, spices, chaotic energy
markets.longDesc: A frenetic Ueno market alley crammed with discount vendors, exotic spices, dried fruits, candy shops, and street food â€” pure chaotic Tokyo energy.

markets.name: Dotonbori Food Stalls
markets.desc: Osaka's neon-lit street food mecca, takoyaki stands, glico sign, grilled everything
markets.longDesc: Osaka's most famous entertainment strip where neon-lit takoyaki stands, okonomiyaki grills, and gyoza vendors create Japan's most exhilarating street food scene.

markets.name: Isetan Shinjuku Depachika
markets.desc: Tokyo's legendary department store food basement, wagashi, bento, gift sweets
markets.longDesc: Japan's most prestigious depachika with exquisitely packaged wagashi, artisanal bento, seasonal confections, and gift-worthy food from every region of Japan.

markets.name: Takashimaya Food Hall
markets.desc: Nihonbashi's premium food floor, curated gourmet prepared foods, luxury gifts
markets.longDesc: An upscale Nihonbashi food hall featuring meticulously curated gourmet prepared dishes, premium Hokkaido dairy, and beautifully wrapped artisanal food gifts.
